channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel Buries 4 Soldiers, but the Mourning Is Marred by Discord
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers at the funeral of Lt. Yael Yekutiel in Tel Aviv on Monday. Lieutenant Yekutiel was one of four Israeli soldiers killed in a truck attack in Jerusalem on Sunday.
item.description: As funerals were held for victims of a truck attack Sunday in Jerusalem, Israelis remained divided over a soldier’s conviction for killing a wounded and incapacitated Palestinian terrorist.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: As Protests Flare, Iran Bids Farewell to Rafsanjani
item.media:description: The funeral in Tehran on Tuesday of Ayatollah Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former president of Iran and a founder of the Islamic republic.
item.description: The top cleric was interred in the tomb of his confidant, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, as protesters cursed Russia and hailed Iran’s reformist heroes.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: American Destroyer Fires Warning Shots at Iranian Boats
item.media:description: The United States guided missile destroyer Mahan in the Mediterranean in 2013.
item.media:credit: Mass Communication Specialist 2nd Class Jacob D. Moore/U.S. Navy, via Reuters
item.description: A Navy warship fired at Iranian boats that raced toward it near the Strait of Hormuz on Sunday, the first such episode since August.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Breitbart’s Man in Rome: A Gentle Voice in a Strident Chorus
item.media:description: Thomas Williams, a former priest, is the Rome bureau chief for Breitbart News.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Thomas Williams, a former priest, gives an organization that sees itself as an expanding empire a foothold in the ancestral home of the Crusades.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Roman Herzog, Germany’s President in 1990s, Is Dead at 82
item.media:description: Roman Herzog, former president of Germany, in 2015.
item.description: A former judge, Mr. Herzog encouraged economic reforms and remembrance of the Holocaust during his presidency, the second since reunification.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Under Pressure, Jeremy Corbyn Tries to Recalibrate His Image in U.K.
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, leader of Britain’s Labour Party, in London last month.
item.description: The opposition Labour leader said he was “not wedded to freedom of movement” in the European Union, opening the way to supporting a so-called soft Brexit.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Goiânia Journal: The Fading Art Deco Dreams of Brazil’s Heartland
item.media:description: Motorists pass a gazebo in Goiânia, which was founded as an outpost of cosmopolitanism in the 1930s.
item.description: As Goiânia’s architectural gems are replaced by nondescript high-rises, the city of 1.4 million offers a glimpse of a country in transition.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: ‘There Are No Homes Left’: Rohingya Tell of Rape, Fire and Death in Myanmar
item.media:description: Rohingya from Myanmar at a refugee camp in Teknaf, Bangladesh, in December. An estimated 65,000 Rohingya have fled across the border, according to the International Organization for Migration.
item.description: From camps in Bangladesh, refugees shed light on the violence that has unfolded in Myanmar in recent months as troops carry out a brutal counterinsurgency.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Bombings Near Afghanistan’s Parliament Kill Dozens
item.media:description: The bombings near the Parliament compound in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Tuesday took place as workers were leaving for the day.
item.description: The attacks came as workers left the Parliament compound in Kabul, killing at least 30 and wounding more than 80. The Taliban claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Memo From China: China Wants to Be a Climate Change Watchdog, but Can’t Yet Lead by Example
item.media:description: A large steel plant in Inner Mongolia, China, in November. To meet China’s targets to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, authorities are pushing to shut down privately owned steel, coal, and other high-polluting factories scattered across rural areas.
item.description: To take on a leadership role to promote the Paris agreement, as China has indicated it wants to do, Beijing will have to be more transparent on emissions.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Militants Attack Police Checkpoint in Sinai, and ISIS Is Suspected
item.media:description: Egyptian officers at the site of an attack on a police checkpoint in El Arish, in the Sinai Peninsula, on Monday.
item.description: The police said the assault involved rocket-propelled grenades and rifle fire as well as a failed attempt to ram the checkpoint with a truck bomb.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: What in the World: Talking to In-laws Can Be Hard. In Some Languages, It’s Impossible.
item.description: A geographically widespread practice known as avoidance speech imposes strict rules on how one speaks — or doesn’t — to the parents of a spouse.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Michael Chamberlain, Father of Baby Killed by a Dingo in Australia, Dies at 72
item.media:description: Lindy and Michael Chamberlain in 1990, when she published a book on the disappearance of their baby daughter, Azaria.
item.description: Mr. Chamberlain and his first wife fought for decades to prove that the animal was responsible for their daughter’s disappearance.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: The Hunger Strike, the Protest Tactic of Gandhi, is Vexing Iran’s Penal Overseers
item.media:description: Amir Raeesian, above, is the lawyer for the hunger striker Arash Sadeghi.
item.description: At least seven Iranian inmates have gone on hunger strikes, and their causes have found traction on social media.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Global Health: Study Finds Lower, but Still High, Rate of C-Sections in China
item.media:description: A maternity ward in a Beijing hospital. A new study found that about 35 percent of Chinese babies were delivered by cesarean section, which is close to the rate in the United States.
item.description: At about 35 percent, the rate is lower than previously reported but still far above the ideal range.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn

item.title: Pope Francis Reiterates Support for Breast-Feeding in Public
item.media:description: Pope Francis baptizing a baby on Sunday in the Sistine Chapel in the Vatican.
item.media:credit: Osservatore Romano, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Crying babies at a Mass in the Sistine Chapel drew remarks from the pope about what he called Jesus’ first sermon, in the manger.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein Official, Quits Northern Ireland Government, Setting Off Shake-Up
item.description: Mr. McGuinness resigned as deputy first minister to protest the government’s handling of an energy subsidy program.
item.dc:creator: SINEAD O’SHEA

item.title: Turkey’s Parliament Starts Debate on Expansion of President’s Powers
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Saturday. Legislation under debate could possibly allow him to remain in power until 2029.
item.description: A proposed constitutional amendment would increase the authority of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and possibly allow him to serve until 2029.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: A Strike Empties London’s Underground. Aboveground Is a Different Story.
item.media:description: Buses were described as “Mad Max-style death trucks.”
item.media:credit: John Stillwell/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: A 24-hour labor walkout by workers for the subway system created a travel nightmare for commuters on a cold and rainy Monday.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.category: National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT)

item.title: Trilobites: Tomatillo Fossils, 52 Million Years Old, Are Discovered in Patagonia
item.media:description: Two fossils of a newly discovered species of tomatillo that are 52 million years old.
item.description: The discovery suggests that the nightshade family of plants, which includes tomatoes, potatoes and peppers, has been around much longer than was previously thought.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: U.S. Commandos Kill Midlevel ISIS Leader in Syria
item.description: The mission’s purpose was to capture and interrogate the leader, but a firefight broke out when the commandos intercepted his vehicle, an official said.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: France Arrests 17, Many From the Time Before Reality TV, in Kardashian Robbery
item.media:description: Kim Kardashian West last year. In October, men burst into the Paris apartment where she was staying, tied her up and robbed her of jewelry worth at least $9 million.
item.media:credit: Landon Nordeman for The New York Times
item.description: The eldest of those detained was 72, and others were in their 40s, 50s and 60s, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Taiwan’s President Meets With Ted Cruz in the U.S., and China Objects
item.media:description: The Taiwanese president, Tsai Ing-wen, right, with Senator Ted Cruz, left, and their respective delegations at a meeting in Houston on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Office of The President Taiwan, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The meeting, en route to stops in Latin America, suggested that President Tsai Ing-wen was seeking to expand the island’s ties to the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON

item.title: Australia’s Health Minister Goes on Leave in Dispute Over Gold Coast Property
item.media:description: Sussan Ley, Australia’s health minister, in March. She has apologized for an “error of judgment” in charging taxpayers for a trip to Queensland.
item.description: Sussan Ley purchased a beachfront apartment while on a taxpayer-funded trip, prompting calls for her dismissal. She apologized but said she had broken no rules.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Southern China Is Blanketed in Smog as Beijing Gets Slight Reprieve
item.media:description: Smog at Victoria Harbor in Hong Kong on Sunday. The worsening conditions have caused the Hong Kong government to warn of a “very high” health risk.
item.media:credit: Chan Long Hei/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.description: Worsening conditions brought unhealthy levels of pollution to parts of southern China, including Hong Kong, on Monday. Beijing’s smog started to clear.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: North Korea, Rebuking Trump, Says It Can Test Long-Range Missile ‘Anytime’
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, in Pyongyang, the capital, in an undated photo. Mr. Kim has said that his country has reached a “final stage” in preparing to test an intercontinental ballistic missile.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: The remarks from the North’s Foreign Ministry came days after President-elect Donald J. Trump expressed doubts about the country’s missile capabilities.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Editorial: Myanmar’s Shameful Denial
item.media:description: Rohingya women near a refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh, in November.
item.description: Brutal attacks on the Rohingya are a stain on the government of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Bannon Versus Trump
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon in December.
item.description: The larger battle is over whether the Republican Party as a whole will become an ethno-populist party.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BROOKS

item.title: Editorial: The Untimely Death of an Iranian Pragmatist
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani in 2016.
item.media:credit: Fatemeh Bahrami/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: Centrists in Iran will have a harder time without Ayatollah Rafsanjani’s help.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
